SEARCH

Class HashedHeap<KT,VT extends Comparable<? super VT>>

java.lang.Object
HashedHeap<KT,VT>
Type Parameters:
KT - The type of hashed keys
VT - The type of values with a natural ordering
All Implemented Interfaces:
Iterable<KVPair<KT,VT>>
public class HashedHeap<KT,VT extends Comparable<? super VT>> extends Object implements Iterable<KVPair<KT,VT>>

Hashed Priority Heap Data Structure

A hashed heap combines the benefits of a hashmap and a binary heap: keys are hashed and values are ordered (Comparable). This compensates for the fact that searching for a value in a heap is O(n). The internal representation uses two arrays, keys and vals. The keys array implements a closed-hash map with linear probing. The vals array implements a binary heap. Each key is mapped to the index in the vals array where the corresponding value is stored. Each value is also stored along with the index in the keys array of the corresponding key. Thus when values are swapped during a heap operation, the key-index information can be quickly updated (no need for hashing/rehashing). The position of keys in the keys array do not change until the entire structure is resized to twice the capacity. As a result, the major operations on the structure will have a practical cost of either O(1) or O(log n). By "practical cost" we mean the average, amoritized running time that discount worst-case scenarios for hashing. Another benefit of this arrangement is improved iterator/stream performance, because values are stored contiguously in the vals array along with the indices of the their keys. Some of the operations on this structure return key-value pairs of the following type: 
 
  public record KVPair<K,V>(K key, V val) {
    @Override
    public String toString() { return key+":"+val; }
  }

  • Constructor Details

    • HashedHeap

      public HashedHeap()
      Constructor creates a maxheap with static initial capacity (default 1024). Values are compared by their natural ordering.

    • HashedHeap

      public HashedHeap(Comparator<VT> vcmp)
      Constructor that accepts a Comparator for the value type; overrides comparison by natural ordering. For example, to construct a minheap with the reverse natural ordering, call new HashHeap<..,..>((x,y)->y.compareTo(x))

  • Method Details

    • set_initial_capacity

      public static int set_initial_capacity(int requested_cap)
      Sets the static initial capacity to the nearest power of 2 that's greater than the requested value. For example, HashHeap.set_initial_capapcity(500); sets the initial capacity to 512. The lowest initial capacity allowed is 2. The default initial capacity is 1024.
      Returns:
      the initial capacity that's set.

    • set_max_load_percentage

      public static void set_max_load_percentage(int percentage)
      sets the maximum load percentage allowed before the capacity of the structure is doubled. The default load percentage is 75.

    • size

      public int size()
      Returns the number of key-values pairs currently in the structure.

    • current_capacity

      public int current_capacity()
      returns current capacity

    • load_percentage

      public int load_percentage()
      return current load percentage as an integer between 0 and 100.

    • and_modify

      public Optional<VT> and_modify(KT key, Function<Optional<VT>,? extends VT> modifier)
      This operation applies the given modifier function to the value, if it exists, that's associated with the given key. If the key is not found, the function is applied to an empty optional to produce a value. In either case the end result is that the value associated with the key will be the value returned by the modifier function. The position of the value in the heap is automatically adjusted. This operation has practical cost O(log n). For example, if the value type (VT) is Integer, then calling .and_modify(key, entry -> entry.map(x -> x+1).orElse(0)) will either increment the value associated with the key by one, or insert a new key associated with value zero.
      Returns:
      the previous value associated with the key, if it exists. Any null key or modifier will result in nothing being done and an empty optional returned. Null is prevented from entering the structure.

    • modify_or

      public Optional<VT> modify_or(KT key, Function<? super VT,VT> modifier, VT default_val)
      Either modifies the existing value with the supplied function or insert the key with default_val as its value. Returns previous value associated with the key, if it exists. This function is designed to be an alternative to and_modify. Calling .modify_or(key,modifier,default_val) is equivalent to calling .and_modify(key,entry -> entry.map(modifier).orElse(default_val)).

    • set

      public Optional<VT> set(KT key, VT val)
      Either inserts or modifies the value associated with the key. Returns the previous value associated with the key, if it exists. This operation is equivalent to calling .and_modify(key, x -> val).

    • push

      public Optional<VT> push(KT key, VT val)
      Alisas for set(KT,VT). Because keys must be unique, this function must first search for the existence of the key before adding a key-value pair to the structure. The usual insertion procedure for binary heaps, which has average cost O(1), cannot be applied, although it is used internally. This operation, like set, has O(log n) cost.

    • get

      public Optional<VT> get(KT key)
      Returns the value associated with the key, if it exists. This operation has practical cost O(1).

    • remove

      public Optional<VT> remove(KT key)
      Removes the key-value pair indicated by the key, returning the value if it exists. This operation has practical cost O(log n).

    • pop

      public Optional<KVPair<KT,VT>> pop()
      Removes the highest priority key-value pair from the structure. This operation has practical cost O(log n).

    • peek

      public Optional<KVPair<KT,VT>> peek()
      Returns the highest priority key-value pair without removing it. This operation has worst-case cost O(1).

    • clear

      public void clear()
      Empties structure of all entries. This is an O(1) operation.

    • stream

      public Stream<KVPair<KT,VT>> stream()
      Returns a stream of key-value pairs in no particular order, except that the first value streamed will have highest priority.

    • iterator

      public Iterator<KVPair<KT,VT>> iterator()
      Implements the Iterable interface by extracting the iterator from stream().
      Specified by:
      iterator in interface Iterable<KT>

    • priority_stream

      public Stream<KVPair<KT,VT>> priority_stream()
      Returns a consuming stream of key-value pairs in order of priority. Running this stream is equivalent to repeatedly calling pop(), and will empty the structure of all keys and values. For example, calling .priority_stream().forEach(System.out::println) will print all key-value pairs in order of highest to lowest priority.
